title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to provide detailed reporting of nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for nursing staff by staff level. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to meet this requirement. The Secretary will redesign nursing facility cost reports with input from private sector accountants. New quality measures will be developed in consultation with experts for use in the payment system. Quality measures for the payment system will be developed with input from experts and various stakeholders. Measures may include process, structural, and outcome indicators that are valid, reliable, and minimize provider burden. Quality measures for the payment system will be developed with input from experts and stakeholders to minimize provider burden and increase accuracy. Measures will address nursing home staffing levels and make provisions for small skilled nursing facilities. The Secretary will post new quality performance measures on the Medicare program website when implemented. The Secretary will post new quality performance measures on the Medicare program website when implemented, linking payments to quality performance by maintaining fiscal year 2005 payment rates as a floor and developing payment adjustment methods. The Secretary will establish payment rates under this section linked to quality performance indicators, developed in consultation with various stakeholders. The Secretary will establish payment rates linked to quality performance indicators for skilled nursing facilities, with methods tested through pilot studies and other appropriate means. Quality measures and new payment methods should be developed and tested within a specified deadline. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including an examination of current and future financing options. The development and testing of quality measures and new payment methods for skilled nursing facilities must be completed within 54 months of the enactment of this subsection. The study will assess Medicaid financing for nursing facility care, including adequacy, Medicare cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, demographic changes, and options for payment and financing over the next five decades. The Secretary will provide annual reports to Congress on payment options for nursing facility services and financing long-term care over the next five decades. Additionally, a final report will be submitted within 5 years, including the results of a study on the impact of amendments on skilled nursing facility care quality. The Secretary will provide annual reports to Congress on payment options for nursing facility services and financing long-term care. A final report will be submitted within 5 years, including the study results on amendments' impact on skilled nursing facility care quality, recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system, and an analysis of alternative approaches to addressing identified issues.
